column2: This story should teach us to think quickly and clearly upon all occasions; for had Jane Gladys not remembered that she owned the bear he probably would have eaten her before the bell rang.
column3: This story should teach us to think quickly and clearly upon all occasions; for had Jane Gladys not remembered that she owned the bear he probably would have eaten her before the bell rang.

column2: THE ENCHANTED TYPES
column3: THE ENCHANTED TYPES

column2: One time a knook became tired of his beautiful life and longed for something new to do.
column3: One time a knook became tired of his beautiful life and longed for something new to do.

column2: The knooks have more wonderful powers than any other immortal folk--except, perhaps, the fairies and ryls.
column3: The knooks have more wonderful powers than any other immortal folk-except, perhaps, the fairies and r y l s.

column2: So one would suppose that a knook who might gain anything he desired by a simple wish could not be otherwise than happy and contented.
column3: So one would suppose that a knook who might gain anything he desired by a simple wish could not be otherwise than happy and contented.

column2: But such was not the case with Popopo, the knook we are speaking of.
column3: But such was not the case with Popopo, the knook we are speaking of.

column2: He had lived thousands of years, and had enjoyed all the wonders he could think of.
column3: He had lived thousands of years, and had enjoyed all the wonders he could think of.

column2: Yet life had become as tedious to him now as it might be to one who was unable to gratify a single wish.
column3: Yet life had become as tedious to him now as it might be to one who was unable to gratify a single wish.

column2: Finally, by chance, Popopo thought of the earth people who dwell in cities, and so he resolved to visit them and see how they lived. This would surely be fine amusement, and serve to pass away many wearisome hours.
column3: Finally, by chance, Popopo thought of the earth people who dwell in cities, and so he resolved to visit them and see how they lived. This would surely be fine amusement, and serve to pass away many wearisome hours.

column2: Therefore one morning, after a breakfast so dainty that you could scarcely imagine it, Popopo set out for the earth and at once was in the midst of a big city.
column3: Therefore one morning, after a breakfast so dainty that you could scarcely imagine it, Popopo set out for the earth and at once was in the midst of a big city.

column2: His own dwelling was so quiet and peaceful that the roaring noise of the town startled him.
column3: His own dwelling was so quiet and peaceful that the roaring noise of the town startled him.

column2: His nerves were so shocked that before he had looked around three minutes he decided to give up the adventure, and instantly returned home.
column3: His nerves were so shocked that before he had looked around three minutes he decided to give up the adventure, and instantly returned home.

column2: This satisfied for a time his desire to visit the earth cities, but soon the monotony of his existence again made him restless and gave him another thought.
column3: This satisfied for a time his desire to visit the earth cities, but soon the monotony of his existence again made him restless and gave him another thought.

column2: At night the people slept and the cities would be quiet.
column3: At night the people slept and the cities would be quiet.

column2: He would visit them at night.
column3: He would visit them at night.

column2: So at the proper time Popopo transported himself in a jiffy to a great city, where he began wandering about the streets.
column3: So at the proper time Popopo transported himself in a jiffy to a great city, where he began wandering about the streets.

column2: Everyone was in bed.
column3: Everyone was in bed.

column2: No wagons rattled along the pavements; no throngs of busy men shouted and halloaed.
column3: No wagons rattled along the pavements; no throngs of busy men shouted and halloaed.

column2: Even the policemen slumbered slyly and there happened to be no prowling thieves abroad.
column3: Even the policemen slumbered slyly and there happened to be no prowling thieves abroad.

column2: His nerves being soothed by the stillness, Popopo began to enjoy himself.
column3: His nerves being soothed by the stillness, Popopo began to enjoy himself.

column2: He entered many of the houses and examined their rooms with much curiosity.
column3: He entered many of the houses and examined their rooms with much curiosity.

column2: Locks and bolts made no difference to a knook, and he saw as well in darkness as in daylight.
column3: Locks and bolts made no difference to a knook, and he saw as well in darkness as in daylight.

column2: After a time he strolled into the business portion of the city. Stores are unknown among the immortals, who have no need of money or of barter and exchange; so Popopo was greatly interested by the novel sight of so many collections of goods and merchandise.
column3: After a time he strolled into the business portion of the city. Stores are unknown among the immortals, who have no need of money or of barter and exchange; so Popopo was greatly interested by the novel sight of so many collections of goods and merchandise.

column2: During his wanderings he entered a millinery shop, and was surprised to see within a large glass case a great number of women's hats, each bearing in one position or another a stuffed bird.
column3: During his wanderings he entered a millinery shop, and was surprised to see within a large glass case a great number of women's hats, each bearing in one position or another a stuffed bird.

column2: Indeed, some of the most elaborate hats had two or three birds upon them.
column3: Indeed, some of the most elaborate hats had two or three birds upon them.

column2: Now knooks are the especial guardians of birds, and love them dearly.
column3: Now knooks are the especial guardians of birds, and love them dearly.

column2: To see so many of his little friends shut up in a glass case annoyed and grieved Popopo, who had no idea they had purposely been placed upon the hats by the milliner.
column3: To see so many of his little friends shut up in a glass case annoyed and grieved Popopo, who had no idea they had purposely been placed upon the hats by the milliner.

column2: So he slid back one of the doors of the case, gave the little chirruping whistle of the knooks that all birds know well, and called:
column3: So he slid back one of the doors of the case, gave the little chirruping whistle of the knooks that all birds know well, and called:

column2: Come, friends; the door is open--fly out!
column3: Come, friends; the door is open-fly out!

column2: Popopo did not know the birds were stuffed; but, stuffed or not, every bird is bound to obey a knook's whistle and a knook's call.
column3: Popopo did not know the birds were stuffed; but, stuffed or not, every bird is bound to obey a knook's whistle and a knook's call.

column2: So they left the hats, flew out of the case and began fluttering about the room.
column3: So they left the hats, flew out of the case and began fluttering about the room.

column2: Poor dears! said the kind-hearted knook, "you long to be in the fields and forests again."
column3: Poor dears! said the kind hearted knook, "you long to be in the fields and forests again."

column2: Then he opened the outer door for them and cried: "Off with you!
column3: Then he opened the outer door for them and cried: "Off with you!

column2: Fly away, my beauties, and be happy again."
column3: Fly away, my beauties, and be happy again."

column2: The astonished birds at once obeyed, and when they had soared away into the night air the knook closed the door and continued his wandering through the streets.
column3: The astonished birds at once obeyed, and when they had soared away into the night air the knook closed the door and continued his wandering through the streets.

column2: By dawn he saw many interesting sights, but day broke before he had finished the city, and he resolved to come the next evening a few hours earlier.
column3: By dawn he saw many interesting sights, but day broke before he had finished the city, and he resolved to come the next evening a few hours earlier.

column2: As soon as it was dark the following day he came again to the city and on passing the millinery shop noticed a light within.
column3: As soon as it was dark the following day he came again to the city and on passing the millinery shop noticed a light within.

column2: Entering he found two women, one of whom leaned her head upon the table and sobbed bitterly, while the other strove to comfort her.
column3: Entering he found two women, one of whom leaned her head upon the table and sobbed bitterly, while the other strove to comfort her.

column2: Of course Popopo was invisible to mortal eyes, so he stood by and listened to their conversation.
column3: Of course Popopo was invisible to mortal eyes, so he stood by and listened to their conversation.

column2: Cheer up, sister, said one.
column3: Cheer up, sister, said one.

column2: Even though your pretty birds have all been stolen the hats themselves remain.
column3: Even though your pretty birds have all been stolen the hats themselves remain.

column2: Alas! cried the other, who was the milliner, "no one will buy my hats partly trimmed, for the fashion is to wear birds upon them.
column3: Alas! cried the other, who was the milliner, "no one will buy my hats partly trimmed, for the fashion is to wear birds upon them.

column2: And if I cannot sell my goods I shall be utterly ruined."
column3: And if I cannot sell my goods I shall be utterly ruined."

column2: Then she renewed her sobbing and the knook stole away, feeling a little ashamed to realized that in his love for the birds he had unconsciously wronged one of the earth people and made her unhappy.
column3: Then she renewed her sobbing and the knook stole away, feeling a little ashamed to realized that in his love for the birds he had unconsciously wronged one of the earth people and made her unhappy.

column2: This thought brought him back to the millinery shop later in the night, when the two women had gone home.
column3: This thought brought him back to the millinery shop later in the night, when the two women had gone home.

column2: He wanted, in some way, to replace the birds upon the hats, that the poor woman might be happy again.
column3: He wanted, in some way, to replace the birds upon the hats, that the poor woman might be happy again.

column2: So he searched until he came upon a nearby cellar full of little gray mice, who lived quite undisturbed and gained a livelihood by gnawing through the walls into neighboring houses and stealing food from the pantries.
column3: So he searched until he came upon a nearby cellar full of little gray mice, who lived quite undisturbed and gained a livelihood by gnawing through the walls into neighboring houses and stealing food from the pantries.

column2: Here are just the creatures, thought Popopo, "to place upon the woman's hats.
column3: Here are just the creatures, thought Popopo, "to place upon the woman's hats.

column2: Their fur is almost as soft as the plumage of the birds, and it strikes me the mice are remarkably pretty and graceful animals.
column3: Their fur is almost as soft as the plumage of the birds, and it strikes me the mice are remarkably pretty and graceful animals.

column2: Moreover, they now pass their lives in stealing, and were they obliged to remain always upon women's hats their morals would be much improved."
column3: Moreover, they now pass their lives in stealing, and were they obliged to remain always upon women's hats their morals would be much improved."

column2: So he exercised a charm that drew all the mice from the cellar and placed them upon the hats in the glass case, where they occupied the places the birds had vacated and looked very becoming--at least, in the eyes of the unworldly knook.
column3: So he exercised a charm that drew all the mice from the cellar and placed them upon the hats in the glass case, where they occupied the places the birds had vacated and looked very becoming-at least, in the eyes of the unworldly knook.

column2: To prevent their running about and leaving the hats Popopo rendered them motionless, and then he was so pleased with his work that he decided to remain in the shop and witness the delight of the milliner when she saw how daintily her hats were now trimmed.
column3: To prevent their running about and leaving the hats Popopo rendered them motionless, and then he was so pleased with his work that he decided to remain in the shop and witness the delight of the milliner when she saw how daintily her hats were now trimmed.

column2: She came in the early morning, accompanied by her sister, and her face wore a sad and resigned expression.
column3: She came in the early morning, accompanied by her sister, and her face wore a sad and resigned expression.

column2: After sweeping and dusting the shop and drawing the blinds she opened the glass case and took out a hat.
column3: After sweeping and dusting the shop and drawing the blinds she opened the glass case and took out a hat.

column2: But when she saw a tiny gray mouse nestling among the ribbons and laces she gave a loud shriek, and, dropping the hat, sprang with one bound to the top of the table.
column3: But when she saw a tiny gray mouse nestling among the ribbons and laces she gave a loud shriek, and, dropping the hat, sprang with one bound to the top of the table.

column2: The sister, knowing the shriek to be one of fear, leaped upon a chair and exclaimed:
column3: The sister, knowing the shriek to be one of fear, leaped upon a chair and exclaimed:

column2: What is it?	What is it?
column3: true

column2: Oh! what is it?"
column3: Oh! what is it?"

column2: A mouse! gasped the milliner, trembling with terror.
column3: A mouse! gasped the milliner, trembling with terror.

column2: Popopo, seeing this commotion, now realized that mice are especially disagreeable to human beings, and that he had made a grave mistake in placing them upon the hats; so he gave a low whistle of command that was heard only by the mice.
column3: Popopo, seeing this commotion, now realized that mice are especially disagreeable to human beings, and that he had made a grave mistake in placing them upon the hats; so he gave a low whistle of command that was heard only by the mice.

column2: Instantly they all jumped from the hats, dashed out the open door of the glass case and scampered away to their cellar.
column3: Instantly they all jumped from the hats, dashed out the open door of the glass case and scampered away to their cellar.

column2: But this action so frightened the milliner and her sister that after giving several loud screams they fell upon their backs on the floor and fainted away.
column3: But this action so frightened the milliner and her sister that after giving several loud screams they fell upon their backs on the floor and fainted away.

column2: Popopo was a kind-hearted knook, but on witnessing all this misery, caused by his own ignorance of the ways of humans, he straightway wished himself at home, and so left the poor women to recover as best they could.
column3: Popopo was a kind hearted knook, but on witnessing all this misery, caused by his own ignorance of the ways of humans, he straightway wished himself at home, and so left the poor women to recover as best they could.

column2: Yet he could not escape a sad feeling of responsibility, and after thinking upon the matter he decided that since he had caused the milliner's unhappiness by freeing the birds, he could set the matter right by restoring them to the glass case.
column3: Yet he could not escape a sad feeling of responsibility, and after thinking upon the matter he decided that since he had caused the milliner's unhappiness by freeing the birds, he could set the matter right by restoring them to the glass case.

column2: He loved the birds, and disliked to condemn them to slavery again; but that seemed the only way to end the trouble.
column3: He loved the birds, and disliked to condemn them to slavery again; but that seemed the only way to end the trouble.

column2: So he set off to find the birds.
column3: So he set off to find the birds.

column2: They had flown a long distance, but it was nothing to Popopo to reach them in a second, and he discovered them sitting upon the branches of a big chestnut tree and singing gayly.
column3: They had flown a long distance, but it was nothing to Popopo to reach them in a second, and he discovered them sitting upon the branches of a big chestnut tree and singing gayly.

column2: When they saw the knook the birds cried:
column3: When they saw the knook the birds cried:

column2: Thank you, Popopo.	Thank you, Popopo.
column3: true

column2: Thank you for setting us free."
column3: Thank you for setting us free."

column2: Do not thank me, returned the knook, "for I have come to send you back to the millinery shop."
column3: Do not thank me, returned the knook, "for I have come to send you back to the millinery shop."

column2: Why? demanded a blue jay, angrily, while the others stopped their songs.
column3: Why? demanded a blue jay, angrily, while the others stopped their songs.

column2: Because I find the woman considers you her property, and your loss has caused her much unhappiness, answered Popopo.
column3: Because I find the woman considers you her property, and your loss has caused her much unhappiness, answered Popopo.

column2: But remember how unhappy we were in her glass case, said a robin redbreast, gravely.
column3: But remember how unhappy we were in her glass case, said a robin redbreast, gravely.

column2: And as for being her property, you are a knook, and the natural guardian of all birds; so you know that Nature created us free.	And as for being her property, you are a knook, and the natural guardian of all birds; so you know that Nature created us free.
column3: true

column2: To be sure, wicked men shot and stuffed us, and sold us to the milliner; but the idea of our being her property is nonsense!"
column3: To be sure, wicked men shot and stuffed us, and sold us to the milliner; but the idea of our being her property is nonsense!"

column2: Popopo was puzzled.
column3: Popopo was puzzled.

column2: If I leave you free, he said, "wicked men will shoot you again, and you will be no better off than before."
column3: If I leave you free, he said, "wicked men will shoot you again, and you will be no better off than before."

column2: Pooh! exclaimed the blue jay, "we cannot be shot now, for we are stuffed.
column3: Pooh! exclaimed the blue jay, "we cannot be shot now, for we are stuffed.

column2: Indeed, two men fired several shots at us this morning, but the bullets only ruffled our feathers and buried themselves in our stuffing.
column3: Indeed, two men fired several shots at us this morning, but the bullets only ruffled our feathers and buried themselves in our stuffing.

column2: We do not fear men now."
column3: We do not fear men now."

column2: Listen! said Popopo, sternly, for he felt the birds were getting the best of the argument; "the poor milliner's business will be ruined if I do not return you to her shop.
column3: Listen! said Popopo, sternly, for he felt the birds were getting the best of the argument; "the poor milliner's business will be ruined if I do not return you to her shop.

column2: It seems you are necessary to trim the hats properly.
column3: It seems you are necessary to trim the hats properly.

column2: It is the fashion for women to wear birds upon their headgear.
column3: It is the fashion for women to wear birds upon their headgear.

column2: So the poor milliner's wares, although beautified by lace and ribbons, are worthless unless you are perched upon them."
column3: So the poor milliner's wares, although beautified by lace and ribbons, are worthless unless you are perched upon them."

column2: Fashions, said a black bird, solemnly, "are made by men.
column3: Fashions, said a black bird, solemnly, "are made by men.

column2: What law is there, among birds or knooks, that requires us to be the slaves of fashion?"
column3: What law is there, among birds or knooks, that requires us to be the slaves of fashion?"

column2: What have we to do with fashions, anyway? screamed a linnet.
column3: What have we to do with fashions, anyway? screamed a linnet.

column2: If it were the fashion to wear knooks perched upon women's hats would you be contented to stay there?	If it were the fashion to wear knooks perched upon women's hats would you be contented to stay there?

column2: Answer me, Popopo!"
column3: Answer me, Popopo!"

column2: But Popopo was in despair.
column3: But Popopo was in despair.

column2: He could not wrong the birds by sending them back to the milliner, nor did he wish the milliner to suffer by their loss.
column3: He could not wrong the birds by sending them back to the milliner, nor did he wish the milliner to suffer by their loss.

column2: So he went home to think what could be done.
column3: So he went home to think what could be done.

column2: After much meditation he decided to consult the king of the knooks, and going at once to his majesty he told him the whole story.
column3: After much meditation he decided to consult the king of the knooks, and going at once to his majesty he told him the whole story.

column2: The king frowned.
column3: The king frowned.

column2: This should teach you the folly of interfering with earth people, he said.
column3: This should teach you the folly of interfering with earth people, he said.

column2: But since you have caused all this trouble, it is your duty to remedy it.	But since you have caused all this trouble, it is your duty to remedy it.
column3: true

column2: Our birds cannot be enslaved, that is certain; therefore you must have the fashions changed, so it will no longer be stylish for women to wear birds upon their hats."
column3: Our birds cannot be enslaved, that is certain; therefore you must have the fashions changed, so it will no longer be stylish for women to wear birds upon their hats."

column2: How shall I do that? asked Popopo.
column3: How shall I do that? asked Popopo.

column2: Easily enough.	Easily enough.
column3: true

column2: Fashions often change among the earth people, who tire quickly of any one thing.
column3: Fashions often change among the earth people, who tire quickly of any one thing.

column2: When they read in their newspapers and magazines that the style is so-and-so, they never question the matter, but at once obey the mandate of fashion.
column3: When they read in their newspapers and magazines that the style is so and so, they never question the matter, but at once obey the mandate of fashion.

column2: So you must visit the newspapers and magazines and enchant the types."
column3: So you must visit the newspapers and magazines and enchant the types."

column2: Enchant the types! echoed Popopo, in wonder.
column3: Enchant the types! echoed Popopo, in wonder.

column2: Just so.	Just so.

column2: Make them read that it is no longer the fashion to wear birds upon hats.

column2: Popopo thanked the wise king and followed his advice.
column3: Popopo thanked the wise king and followed his advice.

column2: The office of every newspaper and magazine in the city was visited by the knook, and then he went to other cities, until there was not a publication in the land that had not a "new fashion note" in its pages.
column3: The office of every newspaper and magazine in the city was visited by the knook, and then he went to other cities, until there was not a publication in the land that had not a "new fashion note" in its pages.

column2: Sometimes Popopo enchanted the types, so that whoever read the print would see only what the knook wished them to.
column3: Sometimes Popopo enchanted the types, so that whoever read the print would see only what the knook wished them to.

column2: Sometimes he called upon the busy editors and befuddled their brains until they wrote exactly what he wanted them to.
column3: Sometimes he called upon the busy editors and befuddled their brains until they wrote exactly what he wanted them to.

column2: Mortals seldom know how greatly they are influenced by fairies, knooks and ryls, who often put thoughts into their heads that only the wise little immortals could have conceived.
column3: Mortals seldom know how greatly they are influenced by fairies, knooks and r y l s, who often put thoughts into their heads that only the wise little immortals could have conceived.

column2: The following morning when the poor milliner looked over her newspaper she was overjoyed to read that "no woman could now wear a bird upon her hat and be in style, for the newest fashion required only ribbons and laces."
column3: The following morning when the poor milliner looked over her newspaper she was overjoyed to read that "no woman could now wear a bird upon her hat and be in style, for the newest fashion required only ribbons and laces."

column2: Popopo after this found much enjoyment in visiting every millinery shop he could find and giving new life to the stuffed birds which were carelessly tossed aside as useless.
column3: Popopo after this found much enjoyment in visiting every millinery shop he could find and giving new life to the stuffed birds which were carelessly tossed aside as useless.

column2: And they flew to the fields and forests with songs of thanks to the good knook who had rescued them.
column3: And they flew to the fields and forests with songs of thanks to the good knook who had rescued them.

column2: Sometimes a hunter fires his gun at a bird and then wonders why he did not hit it.
column3: Sometimes a hunter fires his gun at a bird and then wonders why he did not hit it.

column2: But, having read this story, you will understand that the bird must have been a stuffed one from some millinery shop, which cannot, of course, be killed by a gun.
